Corentin Briat (Oct 02 2025 at 06:55):

@Joe Moeller Thanks :) Happy to discuss with all of you!

Corentin Briat (Oct 02 2025 at 06:56):

@fosco I will look into this book again. I looked into it like 10 years ago, but with different interests in mind. Maybe it will resonate differently this time! Thanks for bringing this up!

David Corfield (Oct 02 2025 at 09:39):

Hi @Corentin Briat. You may be interested in the topic of a lengthy discussion we had this summer on 'Networks in biology'. Too much to condense, but I came away with an appreciation for the approach of this book, Symmetries of Living Systems.

John Baez (Oct 02 2025 at 09:48):

Hi, @Corentin Briat!

As another participant in that discussion, I agree that this is a fascinating book.

@Evan Patterson, @Adittya Chaudhuri and I have been working on gene regulatory networks and Systems Biology Graphical Notation using category theory:

  • Rebekah Aduddell, James Fairbanks, Amit Kumar, Pablo S. Ocal, Evan Patterson and Brandon T. Shapiro, A compositional account of motifs, mechanisms, and dynamics in biochemical regulatory networks.

  • Adittya Chaudhuri, Ralf Köhl and Olaf Wolkenhauer, A mathematical framework to study organising principles in graphical representations of biochemical processes.

  • John Baez and Adittya Chaudhuri, Graphs with polarities.

My paper with Adittya builds on the paper by Aduddell et al, going deeper into some aspects of the math, so it probably pays to focus on their paper first.

Anyway, there are a bunch of us here interested in biology, though no experts I think.

Corentin Briat (Oct 02 2025 at 10:01):

Hi @David Corfield, thanks for letting me know. I will have a look at the thread and the book you are mentioning.

Corentin Briat (Oct 02 2025 at 10:10):

Hi @John Baez, thanks a lot! I will have a look at your papers, they look very interesting. In the meantime, I can share those ones that may be of interest to you:

  • Antithetic Integral Feedback Ensures Robust Perfect Adaptation in Noisy Biomolecular Networks: A paper on structural/robust perfect adaptation in reaction networks. It should be open access, otherwise there is an arxiv version of this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1410.6064
  • Noise in Biomolecular Systems: Modeling, Analysis, and Control Implications: A survey/review/opinion article on biology, control, noise, etc.

Christopher Townsend (Oct 02 2025 at 15:54):

I'm Christopher Townsend - new to this forum, but long time Locale Theorist (if there is such a thing!). My papers are (mostly) on christophertownsend.org if you'd like context for my work. My focus is on the power locales and how we can use them to give a purely locale theory based approach to topos theory. The idea is that the true 'object of study' is a category of locales (suitably axiomatised ...) rather than an elementary topos, so that the toposes are 'just' the discrete objects. For example we can represent geometric morphisms as adjunctions between categories of locales and can see the hyperconnected localic factorisation as a relatively trivial categorical construction when viewed in this way.

Nathanael Arkor (Oct 02 2025 at 15:57):

Hi Christopher – I recently came across your A Categorical proof of the equivalence of Local Compactness and Exponentiability in Locale Theory, which I really enjoyed. The proof is very slick!

Fernando Yamauti (Oct 02 2025 at 16:43):

Christopher Townsend said:

For example we can represent geometric morphisms as adjunctions between categories of locales and can see the hyperconnected localic factorisation as a relatively trivial categorical construction when viewed in this way.

So it's easier to prove the hyperconnected-localic factorisation after passing to internal locales. I don't recall ever seeing that. Is that perhaps written somewhere I can read?

Christopher Townsend (Oct 02 2025 at 18:33):

Fernando Yamauti said:

Christopher Townsend said:

For example we can represent geometric morphisms as adjunctions between categories of locales and can see the hyperconnected localic factorisation as a relatively trivial categorical construction when viewed in this way.

So it's easier to prove the hyperconnected-localic factorisation after passing to internal locales. I don't recall ever seeing that. Is that perhaps written somewhere I can read?

The real categorical essence is Lemma 4.2 here [*]; Proposition 8.2 of the same paper gives the factorization explicitly via the 'localic' methods.

[*] Hilsum-Skandalis maps as Frobenius adjunctions with application to geometric morphisms Tbilisi Mathematical Journal Volume 10 Issue 3 (2017),  83-119.

http://www.christophertownsend.org/Documents/HilsumSkandalisFrobenius.pdf

Fernando Yamauti (Oct 03 2025 at 05:37):

Christopher Townsend said:

The real categorical essence is Lemma 4.2 here [*]; Proposition 8.2 of the same paper gives the factorization explicitly via the 'localic' methods.

[*] Hilsum-Skandalis maps as Frobenius adjunctions with application to geometric morphisms Tbilisi Mathematical Journal Volume 10 Issue 3 (2017),  83-119.

http://www.christophertownsend.org/Documents/HilsumSkandalisFrobenius.pdf

Thanks! I didn't know about this characterisation of geometric morphisms using Frobeniusness. On related note, in quantale theory, people seem to prefer internal suplattices instead of internal discrete locales.

Corentin Briat (Oct 04 2025 at 17:38):

John Baez said:

  • Rebekah Aduddell, James Fairbanks, Amit Kumar, Pablo S. Ocal, Evan Patterson and Brandon T. Shapiro, A compositional account of motifs, mechanisms, and dynamics in biochemical regulatory networks.

I have started reading this one, which is very interesting so far. I published a few things on sign matrices with applications to stochastic reaction networks. For instance,

  • Sign properties of Metzler matrices with applications
  • Ergodicity, Output-Controllability, and Antithetic Integral Control of Uncertain Stochastic Reaction Networks

I am eager to see the connections and possibly extensions of those ideas in the context of Category Theory.

Kasra Sammak (Oct 05 2025 at 15:21):

Hello there, my name is Kasra, I just joined this forum, and I'm a bachelors student of Mathematics at Freie Universität in Berlin, Germany, currently writing my bachelors thesis on the topic of concrete dualities.

I have been studying category theory for 1 year now; this time last year I started a course in topos theory and since then it has been the central language of another course I have taken Algebra II (which was this functorial perspective of scheme theory/algebraic geometry) and it is central to my thesis topic as well.

I really appreciate this way of thinking, and as I get closer to the submission of my thesis, I become more curious about where I could take this knowledge. So, I would like to learn more and stay connected.

Christopher Townsend (Oct 07 2025 at 17:02):

@David Michael Roberts --- indeed. --- torsors/principal bundles over (the core of a) localic category. It was all working out well, until I realised I needed to know something about the classifying localic category (not just groupoid ...) of a geometric theory. This has led me to spend ages on the Vietoris construction so have not finished on the work we were talking about.

Jay (Oct 11 2025 at 00:15):

Hello everyone, I am Jay. I am a Maths undergraduate who wants to "do Category Theory" for their project. I've been given a few books to go through by my supervisor such as "Seven Sketches in Compositionality" and "Basic Category Theory by Tom Leinster" (This is the main one I am reading, I am just over a quarter of the way through it about to move onto Chapter 3) but I am finding it hard to follow some of the examples with my limited knowledge on Topology. I am going to learn some Topology this year in my degree but I don't want to leave my project until then to start. Are there any specific parts of Topology I should focus on if I plan to do my project on Category Theory? Through perusing Wikipedia, I see it becomes a lot more important if I want to learn about Higher Category Theory, which I think I do.

Also, if you would recommend any other books or other resources for learning about Category Theory feel free to share them with me (I have found a few YouTube channels with folders on Category Theory as well as the Reddit page, which lead me here, not that I understand a lot of it YET). At the moment I am just trying to learn as much as I can about Category Theory before picking a specific thing for my project.

Thanks for anything :)

David Michael Roberts (Oct 11 2025 at 07:31):

https://topology.mitpress.mit.edu/ is a good place to start, perhaps

John Baez (Oct 11 2025 at 09:51):

I was going to say that!

Jay (Oct 11 2025 at 10:41):

That seems like exactly what I need, thank you very much :)

John Baez (Oct 11 2025 at 11:47):

You'll be one of relatively few people so far who have learned topology along with category theory, instead of the more common thing of first learning topology, then learning category theory and seeing that topology gives lots of great examples of category-theoretic concepts.

Elisha Goldman (Oct 13 2025 at 01:58):

I'm one of the people who (somehow, even after starting with Riehl) is learning topology very much after category theory, and it seems way harder than the alternative lol. It seems like it could be a good path in theory but afaict, there's no monolithic resource for it like ex. Sheaves in Geometry and Logic is for the normal way.

Elisha Goldman (Oct 13 2025 at 02:07):

Also, hi!

I'm an undergrad interested in (enriched) category theory especially from an algebraic/logical perspective. My ideal research program would be working with pure category theory to define new math rather than generalize previous theories, and answering questions like "how many ways can some category be concretized". I live near Hopkins/UMBC, and I want to meet more people and get more seriously into research in this Zulip :)

Elisha Goldman (Oct 13 2025 at 02:09):

I love finding new ways to look at things and category theory has a great perspectives:sentence ratio

Ruby Khondaker (she/her) (Oct 13 2025 at 13:24):

Elisha Goldman said:

I'm one of the people who (somehow, even after starting with Riehl) is learning topology very much after category theory, and it seems way harder than the alternative lol. It seems like it could be a good path in theory but afaict, there's no monolithic resource for it like ex. Sheaves in Geometry and Logic is for the normal way.

What about “Topology: A Categorical Approach”?

John Baez (Oct 13 2025 at 13:58):

Yes, that book seems like potentially the right way to learn topology while learning category theory, or after learning category theory. But the right link to that book is this:

https://jterilla.github.io/TopologyBook/

It's free, open-access!

Jonty Male (Oct 17 2025 at 10:49):

Hello! I've had brief conversations with a few of you over the past year or so, but I've finally joined this after @Cole Comfort's great Topos Colloquium talk.

I've recently finished undergrad at Manchester in mathematics, where I primarily studied logic/ML and self studied a lot of CT, however I'm now taking a year out due to disruption throughout my degree, unhappily working in data science. I'm attempting to position myself towards a PhD in ACT, though it's proving difficult as most graduate admissions aren't particularly sensitive to mitigating circumstances! I'm trying to scrape by any research experience I can get, and currently studying Aluffi, Fong & Spivak, and @David Jaz Myers's book along with reading papers, but spare time is limited! I'm rather interested in the general "cybernetics" field, both categorically and historically, along with quantum-related topics which I have too little background in. Hoping to connect with all of you, and keep up to date with events etc, esp. the adjoint school and anyone in need of RAs!
